action.action-desc: Mr. Jenkins of West Virginia (for himself and Ms. Clark of Massachusetts) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and in addition to the Committee on Energy and Commerce, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To amend the Controlled Substances Act to establish a task force to address fentanyl and heroin trafficking.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Fentanyl and Heroin Task Force Act.

subsection.text: The Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 801 et seq.) is amended by inserting after section 520 the following new section:

Not more than one year after the date of enactment of this section, the Attorney General shall establish a task force to be known as the Fentanyl and Heroin Inter-Agency Task Force (in this section referred to as the Task Force).

paragraph.text: coordinate Federal agency efforts to identify, target, and dismantle organizations that traffic fentanyl or heroin;
identify sources of fentanyl and heroin production and distribution; and
provide to Federal, State, and local law enforcement agencies—

subparagraph.text: a description of best practices with respect to handling and disposal of fentanyl;
as necessary, updated information about efforts to identify, target, and dismantle organizations that traffic fentanyl or heroin; and
operational and investigative support with respect to efforts to identify, target, and dismantle organizations that traffic fentanyl or heroin.

paragraph.text: Not later than one year after the date of the establishment of the Task Force, and semiannually thereafter, the Task Force shall submit to Congress a report containing the information described in paragraph (2).
A report under paragraph (1) shall include—

subparagraph.text: a description of the status of fentanyl and heroin trafficking within the United States during the previous six-month period;
a summary of Federal, State, and local efforts to eradicate fentanyl and heroin trafficking and an evaluation of the efficacy of those efforts; and
recommendations of the Task Force with respect to any authorizations by Congress that would enable the Task Force to carry out the duties under subsection (b).

paragraph.text: The Task Force shall include a chairperson and representatives selected by the heads of the following Federal entities—

subparagraph.text: Immigration and Customs Enforcement Homeland Security Investigations;
the Office of National Drug Control Policy;
the United States Postal Inspection Service; and
not more than two additional Federal agencies selected by the Attorney General.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General shall appoint the chairperson of the Task Force.

Members of the Task Force shall serve until the head of the respective entity of the member appoints a new representative to the Task Force. The chairperson shall serve until the Attorney General appoints a new chairperson.
Members of the Task Force may not receive additional pay, allowances, or benefits by reason of their service on the Task Force.
Each member of the Task Force shall have one vote.

Any member of the Task Force may propose to create or alter existing operating rules and procedures consistent with the functions of the Task Force. Any change to the operating rules and procedures shall be adopted only upon a majority vote of the Task Force.
The Task Force shall adopt recommendations under subsection (c)(2)(C) only upon a majority vote of the board.
Six members of the Task Force shall constitute a quorum but a lesser number may hold meetings.
The Task Force may appoint and set the pay of a director.
The director may appoint not more than 10 staff personnel as the director considers appropriate.

paragraph.header: Applicability of Certain Civil Service Laws
paragraph.text: The staff of the Task Force shall be appointed subject to the provisions of title 5, United States Code, governing appointments in the competitive service, and shall be paid in accordance with the provisions of chapter 51 and subchapter III of chapter 53 of that title relating to classification and General Schedule pay rates.
The Task Force and the director, acting with the approval of the Task Force, may procure temporary and intermittent services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code.

Upon the request of the director, the head of any Federal department or agency may detail, on a reimbursable basis, any of the personnel of that department or agency to the Task Force to assist it in carrying out its duties under this section.
The Task Force may, for the purpose of carrying out this section, hold hearings, sit and act at times and places, take testimony, and receive evidence as the Task Force considers appropriate.
Any member or agent of the Task Force may, if authorized by the Task Force, take any action which the Task Force is authorized to take by this section.

Subject to applicable privacy laws and regulations, the Task Force may secure directly from any department or agency of the United States information necessary to enable it to carry out this section. Upon request of the chairperson of the Task Force, the head of that department or agency shall furnish that information to the Task Force.
The Task Force may use the United States mails in the same manner and under the same conditions as other departments and agencies of the United States.

Upon the request of the Task Force, the Administrator of General Services shall provide to the Task Force, on a reimbursable basis, the administrative support services necessary for the Task Force to carry out its duties under this section.

To the extent or in the amounts provided in advance in appropriation Acts, the Task Force may contract with and compensate government and private agencies or persons for services necessary to carry out its duties under this section.

subsection.text: There is authorized to be appropriated $5,000,000 for the period of fiscal years 2019 through 2024 to carry out this section.
For the purposes of this section:

paragraph.text: The term fentanyl includes any controlled substance analogue of fentanyl.
The term heroin includes any controlled substance analogue of heroin.

subsection.text: The table of contents for the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 801 et seq.) is amended by adding after the item relating to section 520 the following:
